image.altText: A woman wearing glasses looks right at the camera.

props.synopsis: Justine and her partner cut their losses and sold their home cheap in the inner suburb of Darwin after months of no takers.

title.children: 'There were no takers at all': Seller loses $100,000 putting home on the market in Darwin

image.altText: A family photo featuring mum, dad, and five kids, posing in front of a scenic rainforest and body of water.

props.synopsis: Queensland's Daintree Rainforest does not have mains electricity — so many residents are burning hundreds of litres of "dirty" diesel fuel a week just to keep their businesses running.

title.children: The world's oldest surviving rainforest has a dirty secret, and residents aren't happy

image.altText: Two police officers sit side by side. Their faces are cut out.

props.synopsis: A string of racist awards shared by members of Northern Territory Police's elite police unit have surfaced during a coronial inquest into the police shooting death of Kumanjayi Walker.

title.children: Further examples of racist awards revealed at Kumanjayi Walker inquest

image.altText: A smiling brown-haired woman puts a 'sold' sticker on a 'for auction' sign outside a house.

props.synopsis: A surge in home loan hardship requests and a record number of quick resales are two signs that Australia is still perilously close to the edge of the mortgage cliff.

title.children: Behind the smiles and sold stickers, there are early signs of illness in Australia's property market

image.altText: Mangoes in trays

props.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest mango growers, Manbulloo Limited, has planted its largest ever patch of new varieties in the Northern Territory.

title.children: Mango grower's biggest planting of new varieties Yess! AhHa! and Now! in the NT

image.altText: A couple looks at each other and smiles

props.synopsis: In a city that is less affordable than Sydney, London and New York to purchase a home, some young Taiwanese people are trying desperately to buy, while others are giving up on the real estate dream altogether.

title.children: In expensive Taiwan, some young people are giving up on real estate to join the 'moonlight clan' instead

image.altText: An image of fire and ashes. Next to it Palestinians searching through the ashes with their hands.

props.synopsis: Israel's leader told parliament the strike was not intended to kill civilians and will be investigated.

title.children: Israeli PM admits something 'went tragically wrong' in strike that killed dozens of Palestinians in Rafah

image.altText: A woman in a black and lime green top, with her hair in tight knots, speaks to a camera as people behind her search in rubble

props.synopsis: The United Nations will hold an emergency meeting to further coordinate the response to the disaster, which has been hampered by the weather and tribal violence in the remote region.

title.children: Woman loses 18 members of her family in PNG landslide as hopes of finding survivors fade

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is facing a call to reverse an "interim" law he introduced more than a decade ago to make a Parliament House department exempt from Freedom of Information requests.

title.children: Parliament House department shrouded in secrecy facing calls for greater transparency

image.altText: a weather map of australia showing rain coverage for the week commencing may 27 2024

props.synopsis: A north-west cloud band will engulf Australia this week, signalling a rapid transition away from the monotonous high pressure systems which have dominated recent weather charts.

title.children: Majority of Australia set for soaking rains with first north-west cloud band of the year forecast

image.altText: Close-up of a bomb being carried under a fighter jet taking off.

props.synopsis: Russia's big, cheap, retrofitted Soviet-era bombs have become one of its most effective weapons in its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Locals who have seen their devastating effects view them as a "super weapon".

title.children: Why Ukraine's hands are tied to stop Russia gaining ground with its new main weapon

image.altText: A graphic of a piggy bank with smoking chimneys with dollar notes in the background

props.synopsis: Australia's largest superannuation funds have doubled their investments in high-emitting companies over the past two years, according to environmental finance group Market Forces.

title.children: Just how green is your super fund? Chances are your savings are being used to fund major fossil fuel projects

image.altText: Image shows congestion and traffic delays. You can see cars, grey road on a gloomy day.

props.synopsis: Nationally, most of us opt to get behind the wheel when it comes to commuting to work. But as one Australian state slashes public transport fares, experts say there's more to do in improving the way we get around.

title.children: As Queensland trials 50c public transport fares, experts say there are more ways to improve our commute

image.altText: A young woman with dark hair and a black dress stands in a softly lit Melbourne apartment.

props.synopsis: A building company used to construct affordable housing under a government program has been linked to a notorious residential construction company that collapsed last year amid legal battles.

title.children: Elise thought she had finally found secure housing. Now she's worried her lease is a 'trap'

image.altText: Rafael Nadal waves goodbye to fans on the court at Roland Garros.

props.synopsis: Fourteen-time Roland Garros champion Rafael Nadal once again refuses to rule out a return to the Paris clay, but tears and cheers flow as he loses his opening match to Alexander Zverev.

title.children: 'I am at peace': Rafael Nadal bids emotional farewell to Roland Garros after first-round exit

image.altText: A row of tents in front of a long building at the Australian National University campus.

props.synopsis: Australian National University students moved the pro-Palestine encampment overnight after police warned them to leave by midday today or face further action including arrests.

title.children: Students move pro-Palestine encampment at ANU to new on-campus site ahead of eviction deadline

image.altText: A woman and a young child lay flowers outside a home.

props.synopsis: The WA government says it will consider making its proposed new firearm laws even tougher after two Perth women were murdered in their home, an incident motivated by domestic violence. But could the legislation have stopped their killer?

title.children: The man who shot dead two Perth women legally owned 13 firearms. Would new gun laws have made a difference?

image.altText: Police tape in front of a river and a bridge in the distance / police looking over the edge of a bridge with a river below

props.synopsis: Police hold serious concerns for the wellbeing of a newborn baby and its mother after a passer-by found "signs of birth" on a riverbank in suburban Sydney.

title.children: Search underway for mother and baby after 'placenta and umbilical cord' found on Sydney riverbank

image.altText: Unidentified woman looks away while holding medical records.

props.synopsis: The federal government has been heavily criticised by the domestic, sexual and family violence response sector following its budget. Today its "rapid review" of how to best prevent violence against women will begin in Sydney.

title.children: Expert panel to tell government how to prevent violence against women and children

image.altText: Two men wearing white jackets and protective glasses look up at a vessel holding red liquid.

props.synopsis: Australian researchers are working on developing drugs that target bugs in the guts of Parkinson's disease patients in a radical new treatment approach they hope will slow or even stop the progression of the debilitating illness.

title.children: Queensland researchers are following a 'radical new way of thinking' in treating Parkinson's disease with the gut

image.altText: A man with a dark polo and tan pants surrounded by signage on a front lawn.

props.synopsis: Queensland's Office of the Independent Assessor has referred the mayor's stated army history to the Crime and Corruption Commission after the details were challenged by a newspaper on Anzac Day. He has since provided his service number.

title.children: Queensland watchdog refers new Townsville mayor's army history to CCC

image.altText: Woman looks at photo of 6-year-old son on her phone

props.synopsis: This mother moved an hour to secure work but she cannot relocate her son until she gets a rental property. She's applied for 58.

title.children: Young mother desperate to reunite with son after more than 50 rental rejections

image.altText: A designed artist's graphic of a man and a kit home.

props.synopsis: These tiny homes were sold to Australians as part of a solution to the nation's housing crisis. The company involved took the money for them but never delivered.

title.children: 'Want my money back': Australians caught in tiny homes 'rip-off' demand action

image.altText: The designer John Galliano in his 60s in a black suit with Kim Kardashian in a silver dress and cardigan at the 2024 met gala

props.synopsis: The latest documentary from the director of Whitney skirts around the issues raised by the anti-Semitism and subsequent revival of former Dior and Givenchy creative director John Galliano.

title.children: John Galliano's racist tirade is presented in all its jaw-dropping horridness in new documentary

image.altText: A plastic container with roast chicken and pork and rice.

props.synopsis: Taiwan's customs officials issue a fine of NT$200,000 ($9,369) to a traveller for attempting to bring a lunch box containing pork into the country.

title.children: Visitor to Taiwan hit with $9,000 fine over 'roast chicken and pork combo' lunch box

image.altText: A netball showcasing Indigenous art is photographed on the ground of a netball court

props.synopsis: Indigenous culture took centre stage in Super Netball First Nations Round, but what are the clubs doing in National Reconciliation Week to form an authentic connection with community? Meanwhile, the Fever have finally been dethroned after a six-week winning streak.

title.children: Super Netball Round-Up: First Nations Round a chance for non-Indigenous players to reflect

image.altText: A woman lying on her side curled up in bed during the day, blowing her nose with a tissue.

props.synopsis: Before you reach for a pricey immunity shot, medical experts weigh in on whether there's anything you can do to avoid a cold if you feel one coming.

title.children: What to do (and avoid) when you feel a cold coming

image.altText: The outside of the Nine Entertainment headquarters in North Sydney.

props.synopsis: Mike Sneesby, chief executive of media company Nine, acknowledges "serious" claims of "alleged inappropriate behaviour" at the network.

title.children: Internal email to Nine staff raises 'alleged inappropriate behaviour'

image.altText: Restaurant owner Deanna Flynn Wallis inside the tavern in Mount Barker.

props.synopsis: For many years, Deanna knew there was something about her that was "different". Now, she's taking part in a rollout of "quiet dinners" for people with sensory needs around food.

title.children: 'Quiet dinners' make eating out positive experience for autistic community

image.altText: Parliament House shrouded in fog.

props.synopsis: It's the government department tasked with protecting Australia's democracy, yet within it bubble accusations of a toxic culture, the silencing of dissent and the routine cover-up of problems.

title.children: It's tasked with protecting Australia's democracy. But inside bubble accusations of a toxic culture

image.altText: Rowland points her finger at a white female security guard, talking strnly to her while the guard has her arm around her back.

props.synopsis: Kelly Rowland accuses Cannes security of racial profiling, Lizzo addresses South Park parody and more entertainment news you might have missed.

title.children: 'I have a boundary': Kelly Rowland makes first statement after being moved along at Cannes

image.altText: Paul Cors with his hand on the scope of a gun wearing protective ear muffs.

props.synopsis: A former deputy mayor who killed his elderly mother almost six years ago has been found guilty of her murder after a jury rejected his mental impairment defence.

title.children: Ex-deputy mayor who killed elderly mother found guilty of murder

image.altText: Hawthorn Hawks signage at the clubs headquarters in Melbourne

props.synopsis: The manager for Alastair Clarkson and Chris Fagan confirms the Australian Human Rights Commission has ended the claim in the wake of the parties failing to find a resolution.

title.children: Mediation talks break down in Hawthorn historical mistreatment case at Australian Human Rights Commission

image.altText: An illustration of an electric car and a petrol car.

props.synopsis: Whether you drive an electric car or are considering making the switch, you've probably been drawn into a discussion about whether they are really better for the climate. To save you from your next barbecue encounter, we have put two cars to the test.

title.children: Are electric cars really greener than petrol cars? We've lined up two SUVs and put them to the test
